Package poker

Class Hand

  • java.lang.Object
    • poker.Hand
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.lang.Comparable<java.lang.Object>
    public class Hand
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.lang.Comparable<java.lang.Object>
    Represents a five-card poker hand, with a value that allows it to be compared to other hands
    Author:
    brendansullivan

    • Constructor Detail

      • Hand

        public Hand​(Card[] c)
        Constructs the best five-card hand from the given cards. Precondition: there are 5 (flop), 6 (turn), and 7(river) cards to account for. If there are 5, then simply find the value of the hand. If there are 6/7, finds all the possible hands and use the best one.
        Parameters:
        c - , the cards to construct a hand from.

    • Method Detail

      • findBestHandSix

        public static Hand findBestHandSix​(Card[] cards)
        Returns the best possible hand that can be made from 6 cards. evaluate all the possibilities and add them to a max heap. Then poll the heap, thus returning the best one.
        Parameters:
        cards - , the 6 cards
        Returns:
        Hand, the best hand that can be made from 5 of the 6 cards

      • findBestHandSeven

        public static Hand findBestHandSeven​(Card[] cards)
        Returns the best possible hand that can be made from 7 cards. Evaluates all the possibilities and add them to a max heap. Then poll the heap, thus returning the best one.
        Parameters:
        cards - , the 7 cards
        Returns:
        Hand, the best hand that can be made from 5 of the 7 cards

      • valueHand

        public static long valueHand​(Card[] cardsInHand)
        Finds the exact relative value of the 5-card hand. Precondition: the length of the input array cardsInHand is five. The first digit of the 11-digit result corresponds to the type of hand: 9 for royal flush, 8 for straight flush, 7 for quads, down to 1 for pair and 0 for high card. The digits beyond that are used to break ties within a given type of hand. As such, all the relevant tiebreaking values will be in an order that makes comparison easy. Example: For a two pair hand, the first digit is 2. After that we compare the value of the higher pair, then the value of the lower pair, then the value of the kicker. Royal flush: 90000000000 Straight flush: 800000000AA, where AA corresponds to the high card of the straight Quads: 7000000AABB, where AA is the four of a kind, and BB is the kicker Full House: 6000000AABB, where AA is the trio and BB is the pair Flush: 5AABBCCDDEE, where AA-EE are the cards in descending order of value Straight: 400000000AA, where AA corresponds to the high card of the straight Three of a kind: 30000AABBCC, where AA is the trio, and BB/CC are the other cards in descending order Two pairs: 20000AABBCC, where AA is the higher pair, BB is the lower, and CC is the kicker Pair: 100AABBCCDD, where AA is the pair and BB-DD are the other cards in descending order High card: 0AABBCCDDEE, where AA-EE are the cards in descending order
        Parameters:
        cardsInHand - , the 5 cards that make up the hand
        Returns:
        a long representing the value of the hand
